sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Differential Scanning Calorimeter (DSC) for thermal analysis of pharmaceutical materials including melting point, glass transition temperature, and crystallinity determination.
sections.scope: Applicable to thermal analysis activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Ensure the instrument is installed in a vibration-free area with stable ambient temperature.
Check that the cooling system (chiller or liquid nitrogen supply) is functioning properly.
Power ON the DSC instrument and initialize the control software.
Allow the instrument to stabilize and perform baseline conditioning as per protocol.
Calibrate the temperature and heat flow using certified reference standards (e.g., indium).
Verify calibration results are within acceptable limits before sample analysis.
Clean the sample and reference pans thoroughly and ensure they are dry.
Accurately weigh 2-10 mg of sample using an analytical balance and record the weight.
Place the sample in the DSC pan and crimp or seal the lid appropriately.
Prepare an empty reference pan in the same manner for use as reference.
Load the sample pan and reference pan into their respective positions in the DSC cell.
Close the furnace lid and ensure proper sealing for controlled atmosphere if required.
Set the thermal program including start temperature, end temperature, heating rate, and purge gas flow.
Start the analysis and monitor the initial phase for any abnormalities.
Allow the analysis to complete and observe the thermogram for characteristic thermal events.
After completion, allow the cell to cool down to safe temperature before opening.
Remove the pans carefully using tweezers and dispose of samples appropriately.
Save the thermogram data with proper identification and perform data analysis.
Clean the sample cell and document all parameters in the analytical record.
precautions: Handle pans carefully to avoid contamination or damage.
Use appropriate sample size to prevent overflow or spillage during heating.
Ensure proper crimping or sealing of pans to prevent sample leakage.
Use inert purge gas (nitrogen or argon) to prevent oxidation during analysis.
Do not exceed the maximum temperature limit of the instrument.
Allow sufficient cooling time before opening the furnace to avoid thermal burns.
Clean spills immediately to prevent contamination of subsequent samples.
Wear heat-resistant gloves when handling hot components.
Perform regular calibration to maintain accuracy of measurements.
